author: VNExplorer
title: The week in whoppers: Biden-Harris flip blame on targeting political foes, media is forced to acknowledge Postâ€™s Hunter-laptop story and more
text: The Biden campaign claimed that former President Donald Trump has "confirmed" plans to jail political opponents if elected. NY Post composite / istock/ Gett Diary of disturbing disinformation and dangerous delusions This tweet: Biden-Harris campaign statement on convicted felon Donald Trump confirming his Project 2025 plan to jail his opponents pic.twitter.com/j9ELJI1J6D â€” Biden-Harris HQ (@BidenHQ) June 5, 2024 We say: Sorry, Biden-Harris. Trump explicitly said claims heâ€™d seek revenge on political foes are â€œwrongâ€ and that the lawfare game â€œhas to stop,â€ or â€œweâ€™re not going to have a country.â€ Still, you have to marvel at Team Bidenâ€™s cojones in (falsely) warning that Trump will do precisely what Democrats have been doing to him. Exhibit A? The bogus felony conviction against him that was 1,000% politically motivated. Spot the difference #1: â€œIâ€™ve done all I can do [to fix the border].â€ â€” President Biden, Jan. 30 vs. â€œIâ€™m . . . using the executive authorities available to me as president . . . to address the border.â€ â€” Biden, Tuesday We say: What a difference a nearing election and sinking poll numbers make. For years, Biden claimed he had no power to fix the border (though he somehow had the power to break it the second he took office, by ditching key measures Trump put in place). Now that a whopping 70% of voters flunk him on the border issue, per a Fox News poll, heâ€™s suddenly discovering â€œexecutive authoritiesâ€ that were actually available to him all along. Still, donâ€™t be fooled: Even his belated actions now are a sham that wonâ€™t end the crisis. Spot the difference #2: â€” NPR Public Editor (@NPRpubliceditor) October 22, 2020 vs. â€œHunter Bidenâ€™s Laptop Makes a Brief Appearance at His Trialâ€ â€” The New York Times, Wednesday We say: Almost without exception, mainstream news outlets â€” on the eve of the 2020 election â€” dismissed The Postâ€™s famous scoop on Hunter Bidenâ€™s incriminating laptop as â€œRussian disinformation.â€ Yet now that Joe Bidenâ€™s own Justice Department has introduced the laptop as evidence in Hunterâ€™s gun trial, outlets are readily discussing the story as if theyâ€™d never denied it at all. This charge: â€œThey were . . . being racist as hell to Alvin Bragg.â€ â€” Rep. Jamaal Bowman (D-NY), Saturday We say:What was â€œracistâ€ about the criticism of Bragg? Even many on the left (CNN commentators, ex-Gov. David Paterson, etc.) have questioned the weakness of Braggâ€™s case and said theyâ€™d have acquitted Trump due to a lack of evidence. Radicals like Bowman really need to find some other card to play besides race. Itâ€™s gotten beyond boring. Compiled by The Post Editorial Board

author: Indigenous Services Canada
title: First Nations leaders and Canada agree on a proposed reform of child and family services
text:
MONTRÃ‰AL , July 11, 2024 /CNW/ - Today, the Assembly of First Nations, Chiefs of Ontario , Nishnawbe Aski Nation and Canada reached a $47.8 billion Agreement on the Long-Term Reform of the First Nations Child and Family Services Program. The Agreement is subject to engagement with First Nations and final approvals by the parties to the Agreement.
This First Nations-led and designed agreement is the product of the cumulative efforts of the First Nations Parties and their unwavering dedication and leadership over the past three years to ensure the rights of their children and communities are respected and upheld.
Building on the Agreement-in-Principle signed between Canada and the Parties that previously dedicated $20 billion over five years in 2021, this Agreement will include $47.8 billion over 10 years, providing stable and predictable funding over a longer period that fully supports a reformed program and accounts for the increased costs of services in remote communities.
Key reforms to the current Program's funding methodology will put First Nations in the driver's seat in delivering child and family services to their communities, with increased funding for prevention, First Nations representative services, post-majority support services that will support youth and young adults past the age of majority, and capital. Program funding will adjust to the needs of First Nations children and families today, and into the future, through adjustments for population, inflation and remoteness.
Over the next three months, First Nations-led engagements will take place across the country to help communities better understand how the Agreement will improve child and family services in their community. We will be working closely with the First Nations Parties during this process, and towards an approved final agreement later this year.
Once the Agreement is approved by the Parties, Canada and the First Nations Parties would file a motion with the Canadian Human Rights Tribunal to seek the end of its oversight over the First Nations Child and Family Services Program, with the goal of implementing a fully reformed Program by April 1, 2025 .
Quotes
"Looking back over the past seven months as National Chief, there has not been a day that I have stopped working for our children. For too many years, we have been fighting to fix a broken child welfare system in the courts. And because of our unity in this fight for justice, we reached a historic turning point today with the largest compensation settlement in the history of this country."
National Chief, Cindy Woodhouse Nepinak Assembly of First Nations
"Today, we stand at the brink of a transformative moment for our children and families. The Agreement on the Long-Term Reform of the First Nations Child and Family Services Program represents a profound commitment to our future, rooted in our sovereignty. By supporting the engagement process led by and for First Nations Leadership, and communicating the benefits of the Agreement, we ensure that the voices of our people guide the path forward, fostering a system that respects our traditions and values."
Abram Benedict , Ontario Regional Chief Chiefs of Ontario
"Since 2016, we have worked to address the unique discrimination faced by remote communities in Nishnawbe Aski territory. Our Chiefs, as the rightsholders, instructed us to approach these negotiations in a good way to reach the best possible agreement. I believe this has been achieved. This draft agreement includes historic reforms on how funding will be adjusted to account for the high costs of delivering services in remote communities. What we have achieved is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. I congratulate everyone involved in this lengthy process. Miigwetch to you all."
Grand Chief Alvin Fiddler Nishnawbe Aski Nation
"This is a pivotal moment for reconciliation in Canada . This reform would put First Nations in the driver's seat delivering child and family services to their communities, because they know better than anyone what they need. It would mean First Nations children can grow up in their families, with the services they need, and surrounded by love and their culture. It would bring us closer to a Canada where every child has a fair chance to succeed."
The Honourable Patty Hajdu Minister of Indigenous Services
Associated links
Final settlement agreement on Compensation and Agreement-in-Principle for long-term reform of First Nations Child and Family Services and Jordan's Principle Stay connected!
Join the conversation about Indigenous Peoples in Canada :
Twitter: @GCIndigenous and @organisation Facebook: @GCIndigenous and @organisation Instagram: @gcindigenous and @organisation
You can subscribe to receive our news releases and speeches via RSS feeds. For more information or to subscribe, visit www.isc.gc.ca/RSS .
SOURCE Indigenous Services Canada
For more information, media may contact: Jamie Monastyrski, Press Secretary, Office of the National Chief, Assembly of First Nations, 613-612-7229, [email protected] ; Genna Benson, Director of Communications, Assembly of First Nations, 613-241-6789, [email protected] ; Isak Vaillancourt, Communications Manager, Chiefs of Ontario, 416-597-1266, [email protected] ; Michael Heintzman, Director of Communications, Nishnawbe Aski Nation, 807-621-2790, [email protected] ; Jennifer Kozelj, Press Secretary, Office of the Honourable Patty Hajdu, Minister of Indigenous Services and Minister responsible for FedNor, [email protected] ; ISC Media Relations: 819-953-1160, [email protected]

author: @nypost
title: Vivek Ramaswamy swarmed by anti-Israel protesters â€” and 'Crackhead Barney' â€” just blocks from DNC
text:
By Josh Christenson Published Aug. 22, 2024 Updated Aug. 22, 2024, 8:28 p.m. ET Anti-Israel protesters swarmed former GOP presidential primary candidate Vivek Ramaswamy as he crossed Union Park in Chicago, just blocks from the DNC.
â€œRacist go home! Racist go home!â€ the demonstrators shouted at Ramaswamy as his security detail formed a bubble of protection around him.
"Vivek Go home! Racist Go Home" Pro-Palestine Protesters shout at Vivek Ramaswamy, make him leave as press swarm him at Union Park near DNC pic.twitter.com/YjS3WEfPlE
â€” Oliya Scootercaster ðŸ›´ (@ScooterCasterNY) August 22, 2024 Explore More What was the 'toilet paper' that fell out of Nancy Pelosi's pants on DNC stage? Tim Walz's coaching history called out after ex-football players hit DNC stage: 'It's strange' Killer dad Chris Watts now blames 'control freak' wife for affair that led him to murder her and their two young daughters It was then that the performance artist â€œCrackhead Barneyâ€ appeared.
â€œWhy are you a genocidal warmonger?â€ she cried.
The internet personality has made headlines for harassing Alec Baldwin in an anti-Israel temper tantrum at a coffee shop in the Big Apple â€” and later hamming it up on â€œPiers Morgan Uncensoredâ€ about the incident.
Barneyâ€™s age and real name are unknown, but the provocateur is based in New York.
4 Vivek Ramaswamy being swarmed by news media and demonstrators as he visits an area that has been a gathering point for protestors outside of the Democratic National Convention. Getty Images 4 â€œCrackhead Barneyâ€ appeared, asking Ramaswamy, â€œWhy are you a genocidal warmonger?â€ she cried. FNTV 4 The internet personality has made headlines for harassing Alec Baldwin in an anti-Israel temper tantrum at a coffee shop in the Big Apple â€” and later hamming it up on â€œPiers Morgan Uncensoredâ€ about the incident. FNTV 4 Ramaswamy waded into the topic of the tense protests himself earlier Thursday, taking note of how well-guarded the Democratsâ€™ convention was from the anti-Israel protesters. FNTV She first came to prominence for getting MAGA rally attendees hackles up as an ambush interviewer in recent years, but has more recently focused on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
Ramaswamy, 39, waded into the topic of the tense protests himself earlier Thursday, taking note of how well-guarded the Democratsâ€™ convention was from the anti-Israel protesters.
â€œIâ€™m grateful that Democrats appear to now agree with Donald Trumpâ€™s policy of building a wall,â€ he said in a press conference at the Trump Hotel Chicago.
â€œIf only they cared as much about keeping illegals out of our country as they do keeping their own left-wing protesters out of their own convention, our border crisis would actually be behind us,â€ he zinged.
Ramaswamy was one of the few Republican presidential primary contenders to oppose further US military aid funding for Israel in its war against Hamas terrorists â€” potentially giving him a point of agreement with the demonstrators who harassed him on Thursday.
He also opposed clamping down on the free speech of college protesters who sprung up on campuses since the Oct. 7 massacre â€” even when it veers into hate speech.
â€œHate speech is the expression of an opinion, and all opinions, no matter how heinous, are protected,â€ Ramaswamy told NBC News last October.
Filed under chicago dnc 2024 vivek ramaswamy 8/22/24 Read Next GOP rep questions whether Trump shooter Thomas Crooks acte... author: Susan Cox
title: Jon Anik says toxic fight fans could lead to career change: â€œI donâ€™t know how much time I have left in this MMA spaceâ€
text: Jon Anik says toxic fight fans could lead to career change: â€œI donâ€™t know how much time I have left in this MMA spaceâ€ UFC commentator Jon Anik is growing tired of toxic fight fans and says a career change could be on the horizon. It was just this past Saturday, at UFC 297, that saw Dricus Du Plessis (21-2 MMA) defeat Sean Strickland (28-6 MMA) to become the new UFC middleweight champion. The split decision victory caused quite a bit of controversy with fans, [fighters](https://www.bjpenn.com/mma-news/sean-strickland/pros-react-after-dricus-du-plessis-dethrones-sean-strickland-at-ufc-297/) and commentators, some believing Strickland should have been given the nod, while others felt Du Plessis was indeed worthy of the win. Jon Anik was one of the commentators who did indeed score the fight for Du Plessis. Apparently, Anik has been attacked by a multitude of fans who believed â€˜Tarzanâ€™s performance was worthy of the win and him keeping the belt last weekend. Anik, speaking on his latest podcast with Kenny Florian, shared his frustration with the malice and disrespect shown to him by fight fans on social media: â€œI am growing tired of this MMA space a little bit, and just the morass of negativity when there is a close fight. Because even if you and I both thought Dricus Du Plessis won the fight, we try to present that information respectfully. And when I go onto X or I go to our YouTube comments, it seems like a lot of these fans are just in attack mode. And I donâ€™t know if these fans are casual fans or not.â€ Continuing, Jon Anik said (h/t [MMAMania](http://www.mmamania.com)): â€œI appreciate the passion, but Iâ€™m getting to a point at 45 years of age where I donâ€™t know how much time I have left in this MMA space. If I go do pro football, Iâ€™m not necessarily gonna be dealing with this lowest common denominator all the time. I donâ€™t know, man. I just feel like thereâ€™s a lot of malice and disrespect from the fan base.â€ Concluding, Anik says heâ€™s â€˜had itâ€™ with all the negativity: â€œWe can disagree. Donâ€™t take it from me. Demetrious Johnson and Kenny Florian thought â€˜DDPâ€™ won the fight. Iâ€™ve just been very off-put with the negativity that has permeated my feed since Saturday night, and Iâ€™m just not sure how much longer I have left in this space â€” honestly. Those of you suggesting that thereâ€™s any bias or you donâ€™t like me, well, youâ€™ll probably get your f**king wish come 2026, because honestly, at this point, Iâ€™ve had it.â€ What do you think of Jon Anikâ€™s commentary that heâ€™s had it with toxic MMA fans? Would you be sorry to see the UFC commentator depart? Share your thoughts in the comment section PENN Nation! Topics: [Jon Anik](https://www.bjpenn.com/mma-news/jon-anik/) [UFC](https://www.bjpenn.com/mma-news/ufc/)

author: @infobae
title: Lara GonzÃ¡lez, autocrÃ­tica: "No es real, estas no son las 'Guerreras'" - Infobae
text: La jugadora de balonmano espaÃ±ola Lara GonzÃ¡lez ha negado que sea "real" la versiÃ³n mostrada este jueves por la selecciÃ³n nacional ante Brasil, con derrota abultada por 18-29 en la primera jornada de los Juegos OlÃ­mpicos de ParÃ­s, y por ello ha afirmado que "estas no son las 'Guerreras'" que tantos Ã©xitos han conseguido en el pasado. "Creo que no es real, creo que estas no son las 'Guerreras', no somos nosotras. Hoy no hemos mostrado esa garra, ese gen que llevamos dentro, y estoy segura que de aquÃ­ a 48 horas o 72 que volvemos a jugar, le vamos a dar la vuelta y por lo menos mostraremos otra cara", declarÃ³ la capitana de la selecciÃ³n espaÃ±ola al canal Eurosport. "Creo que tenemos que hacer un reseteo, calmarnos, volver a la situaciÃ³n un poco inicial, respetar la camiseta que llevamos puesta, respetar todo el trabajo que llevamos haciendo durante mucho tiempo y por todas nuestras compaÃ±eras. Y realmente creo que lo podemos hacer muchÃ­simo mejor, reducir cada uno de los errores no forzados que hemos cometido", indicÃ³ desde las instalaciones del Arena Paris Sud. Pese al mal arranque de torneo, GonzÃ¡lez se mostrÃ³ optimista. "Lo bueno de esta competiciÃ³n es que en dos dÃ­as volvemos a competir, que esto es muy largo, aÃºn quedan cuatro partidos, que es importante tener la cabeza frÃ­a, que esto no es quien gana el primer partido", aseverÃ³. "Queda muchÃ­simo, ahora estÃ¡ en nosotras en hacer una buena digestiÃ³n de este partido, analizar bien internamente cada una cÃ³mo podemos hacerlo mejor", advirtiÃ³ la lateral izquierdo del Rapid de Bucarest. Y en esa lÃ­nea de autocrÃ­tica coincidiÃ³ tambiÃ©n Kaba Gassama, en su caso ante los medios oficiales de la Real FederaciÃ³n EspaÃ±ola de Balonmano (RFEBM). La pivote dijo que el inicio no habÃ­a sido el esperado y que eso las habÃ­a "lastrado durante todo el partido". AdemÃ¡s, lamentÃ³ no haber estado "muy efectivas de cara a la porterÃ­a" y tampoco haber sido en defensa todo lo "compactas" que suelen ser. Pese a ello, Gassama realzÃ³ la actitud de las 'Guerreras', habiendo "intentado remontar esos goles" de Brasil que pusieron todo "bastante difÃ­cil" hasta el pitido final.

author: Pacific Daily News
title: Supreme Court affirms decision in a case involving GPD officers' warrantless search | News | guampdn.com
text: The Supreme Court of Guam on Thursday affirmed the Superior Courtâ€™s decision granting a manâ€™s motion to suppress evidence in a case involving a warrantless search conducted by Guam Police Department officers. A warrantless search is presumptively unreasonable, the upper court said. â€œIn reviewing the trial courtâ€™s decision to grant (Zerxes Jabidando) Vivaâ€™s motion to suppress and the inconsistencies and contradictions in the officersâ€™ accounts, the trial courtâ€™s decision to suppress the evidence was not clearly erroneous. Accordingly, we affirm the Superior Courtâ€™s order granting Vivaâ€™s motion to suppress,â€ the justices wrote. The Dec. 28 opinion was authored by Justice Katherine A. Maraman and joined by Chief Justice Robert J. Torres and Justice F. Philip Carbullido. Because the Superior Court had concerns about the credibility of the peopleâ€™s witnesses, it was not clearly erroneous for the Superior Court to determine that it was unclear whether Viva consented to the search and that the evidence obtained during the search should be suppressed, according to the Supreme Court. GPD Sgt. Ephraim Amaguin conducted a traffic stop after witnessing Viva drive through a stop sign, based on the transcript of the motion to suppress hearing in July 2022. After pulling over, Viva exited the car on his own, and Viva and Amaguin stood in front of the vehicle. According to court documents, the GPD sergeant performed none of the ordinary inquiries of a traffic stop. He did not ask for Vivaâ€™s license or registration, run the plates of the car, check for outstanding warrants, or issue a ticket or citation for failing to stop at the stop sign. Instead, according to Amaguin, he asked Viva: (1) if he was still on probation, to which Viva answered yes, (2) if he had any drugs on him, to which Viva answered no, and (3) for permission to search Vivaâ€™s vehicle, to which Viva gave consent, based on Amaguinâ€™s testimony. However, he later testified that he could not recall when in the string of events this conversation had occurred, court documents stated. According to Amaguin, after obtaining consent, he requested backup to conduct the search and GPD Officer Christopher Champion and trainee Officer Clomera Conner responded to the request. According to court documents, Champion testified he did not ask Viva for consent to search the vehicle. He testified he discovered a large kitchen knife and saw a suspicious message banner on Vivaâ€™s phone that Champion believed to be related to a drug deal but he took no photographs of the message nor did he extract any data from Vivaâ€™s phone. The officers found a baggie containing a substance that tested positive for methamphetamine using a field test. They also found Vivaâ€™s wallet containing $2,000 but itâ€™s unclear from their testimony whether they found the wallet during the search of Vivaâ€™s car or if they discovered it on his person. Champion arrested Viva. The other officer, Conner, testified that none of the officers read Viva his Miranda rights. In contrast, Champion testified that he read Viva his Miranda rights at the precinct. In its decision and order, the Superior Court questioned the truthfulness of the GPD officersâ€™ testimony and ultimately did not find it persuasive. Instead, the trial court found the officers presented inconsistent testimony and that it was unclear whether Viva consented to the search. Ultimately, unable to find that the officers obtained consent, the trial court granted Vivaâ€™s motion to suppress. The Office of the Attorney General appealed the suppression, arguing the trial court did not properly address Vivaâ€™s consent. In affirming the trial court decision, the Supreme Court said â€œthe decision to grant Vivaâ€™s motion to suppress was based on the trial courtâ€™s justified concerns about the credibility of the officersâ€™ testimony, not on a failure to properly address the issue of consent.â€
